div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. div.head: REUTER'S AGENOY.
div.p: '"The-contradictions in the news from India this week have been very remarkable," said the "Manchester Guardian" on Oct. 5, "and it was eee more important than now, when the English people have need to be forming some views about our future policy 'there, that we should have news that will not subside when we begin to build upon it. .

"What Mr. Keir Hardie really said we know from his own telegram to the "Daily Mail," from & telegram sent by the Calcutta corres- pondent of the "Tribune," and. also from 'telegram published from Reateér's correspon- dent to-day. He had drawn a parallel between the Bengal Government and that of Russia only in so far as concerned the ubiquity of the
police and the suppression of public meetings ; the parallel' with Armenia had to do solely

with the violation of Hindu women by Moham- medan rowdies ; and as for colonial government, he had said that that was the ultimate goal, not an immediate object. or right. These ex- . planations may not make Mr. Keir Hardie's speech discreet, but they acquit him of using wild words and rhetorical exaggeration. "Reuter's corréspondent eithet did not know the context of Mr. Hardie's parallels or deli- berately suppressed it, in which case'he was. inflaming English opinion ; and, what is moré, when Mr. Hardie returned to Calcutta he was so careless.or 80 prejudiced that he again 'neglected to give the context, and represented Mr. Hardie's explanations as an exultant justification. Nor is this the first time by any means that Reuter's correspondent has been accused of political misrepresentation ; it is not long since we published a letter from six Caloutta editors pom phainitk ofthe prejudiced character of his news ; but this particular ins- tance, being a personal and simple one, is particularly instructive. It shows that Reuter's correspondent is aman who sees only two' colours, black and white,and that his telegrams are, therefore, not to be trusted asa founda- | tion for judgments in politics, whose colours, |i in India, as here, are mostly greys and browns. - "This is a very serious matter indeed, for Reuter's telegrams are the only materials for opinon on Indian affairs that most people have, and they are thé telegrams mainly read, largely because the Agency has the reputation | of being concerned with the dissemination only of. news, and not of views. When an obijoully tendencious telegram appears iti & strong party organ the reader is on his gttard, and has a | chance of correcting the perspective. The | announcement that a telegram comes through | Reater's 4 Agency gives no such warning, but lulls suspicion. ~ "The country is, in fact, in danger of having
F its opinions.on ute warped by a slow, steady drip of prejudiced news,,as it was in Sonth
Africa, In South Africa the problem of news
collecting was excessively difficult, for the

whole business was in the hands of a wealthy body of men who were determided. thet there | should be no reconciliation, and the home Government was more or less in sympathy with them. The conditions are surely not so-bad in India, 'nor is the India Office committed to a policy which would make satisfaction of legiti- mate Indian demands impossible...... | "Reuters Calcutta sBrfeatoodont to-day," 'continued the "Manchester Guardian," in its | issue of Oct. 7, "sends an explanation of his ees messages on Mr. Keir Hardie's . 8 peech last week. He says that thé statements were NA ieoaied absolutely without qualification {in the "Statesman," and _"'Bengalee," andother papers. That, ifttue, might be held to justify | his first telegram, which was given on the authority of the Bengali papers ; on the other | side, it would have been only fair to Mr. Keir | Hardie to have waited for confirmation of these reports before sending a telegram which he | must have known would greatly agitate opinion tin England. . : . This illustrates our point of ' Saturday that Reuter's cotrespondent showed ' himself a good advocate, but a bad reporter. ' He can please himself whether he believe' Mr. | Hardie or not, but he must also have the good- ness to'let other people' have a chance of pleas- 'ing themselves too ; and his business was to report what Mr. Keir Hardie himself said he | said, especially as he had got Mr. Hardie into trouble by reporting pret other people said he said."

div.head: Tho Cairo Season,
div.p: The Cairo correspondent of the "Daily 'Lelegraph" states that the wedding of Mlle. Bertha de Willebois, tthe daughter of Consul- General for Holland, which will take place~ in 'November; will undoubtedly start the season early forall the diplomatic and official world will return in time to be present.

div.head: Protectien of Children.
div.p: A meeting was held at the Gouvernorat on Saturday night under the presidency of Mus- tapha Pasha. Ibady with the object of forming' a society for the protection of 'Alexandrian children. The aieeting was largely attended, and, subscriptions being called for, a sum of L.E. 240 was promised from among those present.

div.head: Omdurman Trade.
div.p: Trade is still rather dull at Omdurman, notwithstanding the arrival of large quantities of goods, It was hoped that as soon as the railway was opett and goods began to arrive, business would improve. But this hope has not heen realized. Either sufficient time has not yet been given to the miarket to recuperate, says the "Sudan 'Times" or financial matters are still in a straitened condition.

div.head: Tour Eiffel.
div.p: The management of this popular variety hall scored a certain success in departing from its usual programme on Saturday evening, aud presenting to quite a large and thoronghly appreciative gudience a new and skilful turn im the shape of a quick change artist. His sketeh, ine which he acts all the characters, occupies. the whole of the third part of the programme, preceding which a good selection of new variety turns are given, while retaining some of its old favorites.

div.head: Locusts in the Sudan,
div.p: Ina letter to 'the "Sudan Times" Ibrahim Bey Farah Sheikh of the Gaalin-tribes, says that the Sudan was visited by locusts in 1866, the swarms' were"so nomerous and destructive that they devonred almost every thing in their way. Even leather articles and furnitare did not 'escape their depredations, The locusts that ««tppeared there this year, however, were more numerous and would have heen mere destructive had it not been for the prompt and active measures taken by the aiithoritfes to destroy them. He drew.a com- parison between the interest taken. by the Government on this occasion and the lack of jitterest which used to be manifested when the country was visited by similar plagues in the Jays of the old regimes.

div.head: Clayton Cas Co.
div.p: On Saturday afternoon the first trial trip took place of the new steainer for the Alexan- drian station of the Clayton Gas Company Limited. 'This steamer, which has jyst arrived from England, was built by John Rennie and Company of Greenwich specially for the Com- pany's peculiar requirements and is to he - efly used for the disinfection of ships in the urbour. The steamer is fitted with a com- "re disinfecting apparatus and is thus able th proceed alongside any boat reiniring its Mr. F. MacKinnon, the managing Director of the Company, was on board the steamer during. ita trial on Saturday and expresso "1 himself as-thoronghiy satisfied with he behavionr of the craft, everything working with the greatest smoothness. The company expect to disinfect. their first steamer noxt week in the presence of the members of the (Juarantine Board. The next plant to arrive Alexandria is now on its way from England. This consists of a large but portable disinfect- ng apparatus, mounted ona steam waggon and is specially constructed for the purification of public buildings, houses, factories, barracks, ete.

div.head: EGYPTIAN DELTA LAND AND INVESTMENT LIMITED.
div.p: There was a decline on Friday last in the shares of the Egyptian Delta Land and Invest- ment Limited in consequence of a report that the Government hed decided in favour of 'fourah for the sewage farm. If this were troe the estate of the company at Maadi would greatly depreciate in value. According to information received yesterday at Alexandria from Mr. Henriques, the general manager, the company has been definitely informed that the sewage will not be taken to Tourah.

div.head: LORD CROM ER REWARDED.
To-Day's Guildhall Ceremony
THE EMPIRE'S ROLL OF FAME.
div.p: "Distinguished Talent and. Indomitable Energy."

To-day marks one of the most important, as well as one of the most interesting eyents in the history of modern Egypt, when the citizens of London set. their seal upon the life-work of the Empire's great Pro-Consul, the Earl of Cromer, by conferring upon him the greatest honour it is in their power to bestow, and enroling his name amongst the list of royalties, distinguished statesmen, and great warriors who have earned the gratitude of their country by their deeds of goodness, renown, and valour.

This presentation. of this signal and much coveted hononr upon Lord Cromer, which was postponed 'until 'td-day owing .to the state of his Lordship's health, has been, looked forwatd to with great interest both by the Corporation and the people of London.

Our readers will; we.think, be better able to 'understand and appreciate this great ce- remony if we give afew interesting particulars connected with its history. To begin with, London's "Roll of Fame," as all know, dates back from ancient times, but our purpose will be, served if we confine our selection therefrom within the past century or so. The first name. that comes to our notice is that,of his Royal Highness the Prince Regent, afterwards George the Fourth, Then, later in 1840, the much lamented Prince Consort became the recipient of the honour, and in course of time his Royal Highness's four sons, the Prince.of Wales, now our Gracious King Edward the Seventh, the Duke of Edinburgh, the Duke of Connaught, and the late Duke of Albany took up their freedom by patrimony—that is, on attaining their majority they exercised their right to be énrolled as-the sons of a Freeman; their cousin, the Duke of Cambridgeraleo having done so in 1857. The names which next come to our notice are those of great warriors, Lord Nelson, Captain Thomas Hardy, Vice-Admiral Lord Collingwood, The Duke of Wellington, Lord Napier of Magdala, Lord Wolseley, and Lord Kitchener. Of famous statesmen we find the names of William Pitt, afterwards Earl of Chatbam, and in 1784 that of his son the Rt. Hon, William Pitt, who at the age of 24 had been installed as Premier and Chan- ceellor of the Exchequer, of England, Sir Robert Peel, Richard Cobden,. Canning, Bea- consfield, and Gladstone.Of intrepid travel- lers, David Livingstone, and Sir Francis Me- Clintock, who, after many years 'of unsuccess- ful search and untold hardship. and adventu- res finally ascertained the fate of Sir John Franklin and his fellow-explorers in the Arctic regions. There follow such famons numes as the Earl of Shaftesbury, Lord Brougham, Jen- ner, Rowland Hill, Lord John Russell; Gene- ral Grant, the Marquis of Dufferin and Ava, Lord Milner, Lord Curzon, ete., ete.

An interesting episode is connected with the, conferment of the honour upon Lord Nelsoti, After the victorious ending of the Battle of the Nile, Admiral Nelson forwarded to the. Lord Mayor of London the sword surrendered by the Commanding French Admiral Blanquet, with a letter in which he said that, having the honour of being a Freeman of the City of Lon- don, he offered the sword to the Lord Mayor, and requested that the City would honour him by accepting it, "'as a remembrance that Bri- tannia still rules the waves", adding "which thatshe. may ever do is the prayer of your lordship's most obedientservant, Horatio Nel- son." The letter is addressed from "Vangoard", Mouth of the Nile, August 8th, 1798.

There are four methods by which the Free- dom can be acquired (1) by patrimony ; the sons of Freemen being entitled, on attaining their majority, to be enrolled as a matter of right ; (2) by apprentieeship to a master who is 'already a aan: (3) by purchase ; and (4) by gift conferrered by the Corporation, hon- oris causa, This latter is only granted in recognition of very distinguished ,public servi- ces. 'The bestowment of the Freedom is still carried ont according to ancient ceremonial, although this is somewhat modified in the case of ordinary admissions. Six citizens, usually selected from the Chairmen of Com- mittees éf the Corporation, give -their testi- mony to the fitness of the person about to be honoured with the Freedom, stating that he is "a man of good name and fame; that he does not desire the Freedom of this City whereby to defraud the,King or this City of their rights, customs, or advantages, but that he will pay his scot and bear his. lot; and so they all say."

A few facts concerning the Court of Com- mon Council, which has the exclusive right of conferring the honorary' Freedom of the City may not be inappropriate. The Coun- cil consists of 206 members, and shares with the Court of Aldermen, which numbers 26 members, the responsibility, under the Lord Mayor, of the government of the City of London.

The Court is entrusted with the manage- ment of the finances and estates of the Cor- poration, .glects most of the officials, and controls the police. The City also elects a Sheriff of Middlesex as well as of London, and the Lord Mayor is elected by the Trade Guilds in Common Hall from among the Aldermen who have served as Sheriffs.

The Court of Aldermen is of very ancient origin, the first mention of such a Court being found in'an ancient chronicle, where the writer —himself an Alderman—says; lp the year 1200 were chosen fiye and twenty of the more discreet men of the City, and sworn to take counsel on behalf of the City, together with the Mayor."

The City appears to have been governed by the Court of Aldermen before the Common Council was-in existance. The earliest known list of members of this Council is found in the City Archives about the date 1285.

The Guildhall, where this very interesting ceremony takes place to-day, is one of London's most ancient and histotic buildings, It still retains the greater part of the old building which was damaged in the great fire of London in 1666, and was rebuilt by Dance in 1798.
The resolution that the Freedom be conferred upon Lord Cromer was passed at a meeting of the Cort of Common Council held on the 31st of May last, and was in the following terins :—

"Resolved that the Freedom of the City in a snitable gold box be presented to the Hon. Evelyn Baring, Earl of Cromer G.C:B, O.M., K.C.8.L, C.LE., in recognition of the long avd eminent public services he has rendered to bis country, and more especially for the dis- tinguished talent. and indomitable energy he has displayed in the discharge during nearly a quarter of a centary' of thé important and onerous duties which have devolved upon him os the represntative of the British Goveroment in the ancient and historic land of Egypt". .

This was moved by Mr; J. W. Domoney, Chief Commoner, and Chairman of the City Lands Committee, who paid a warm tribute to the work carried out by Lord Cromer. He said that the services rendered by Lord Cromer during his twenty-five years' labours in Egypt were 'quite outside ordinary circumstances, and deserved the greatest recoguition that could be béstowed. It was twenty-five years since Sir
Evelyn Baring went to Egypt. On his arrival
he found.the place in a great «state of chaos, when he left it its administration and poliey—
owing to his wise' and admirable work—were secure and lasting. His straightforward dealing and impartiality in. all his relations with the natives accounted for his cnormovs influence
over them. Sir George Faudel-Phillips, in seconding the
resolution, said Lord Cromer would go down

to history as one of our great pro-consuls, ranking with such men as Lord Clive. He was not born to greatness, but he was aman who, having great opportunities, made great epochs in our national history. There was nothing which could redound to the interest of. this great Empire and add more to its reputation and glory than whathad been done in Egypt. Instead of that country being, as it now is, amongst the most civilised parts of the- globe, it was not too much to say that it would be in the hands of ignorant and despotic rulers, with the result that the trouble to Europe would be irreparable. Lord Cromer had won the con- fidence of men whose only previous' expe-
'riences @f government were a tradition, and

knowledge of. cruelty and. oppression which terrified them—he had first won their confi- denee and then their goodwill. They werd} voting that day to one of their greatest liv: ing statesmen the greatest honour they pos- sessed, and the Corporation, in so doing, was honouring a man who had done wonder- fal'service—a service which had been recognis- ed not only by the people of this country, but by the civilised nations of the world:

The notion was then put and carried una- nimously and with acclamation, and it was referred to the City Lands Committee to make the necessary arrangements in the event of Lord Cromer's accepting the proposed Phe Rt

he Rt. Hon. Sir Joseph Dimsdale, Bt:, K. 0. V. 0., whose duty it will be to present a Freedom to Lord Cromer to-day, 'has been Chamberlain of the City of-London since 1902. Hehas served the City faithfully for | many years and had the great .honour of hold- ing the position. of Lord Mayor during the Corgnation year.

div.head: KAMEL'S PARTY.
div.p: We have received a circular from Mustapha Pasha Kamel asking us if we would like to be members of his own National Party in accord ance with the programme, the ten points of which we published last Friday. His method of forming the party is original and resourceful. | Every one who likes to send him a line saying | that he agrées with bis programme becomes a | non-active member, The active members appat- ently will be his brothers, brothers-inlaw, uncles,consins and other more remote relations, of whom, in Egypt, there-are no limits, and his staff, printers and printers devils.

div.head: ANGLO- BGYPTIAN ARTIST.
div.p: Mr. A. OQ. lasapiough, the noted Anglo- 3gyptian watercolour artist whose exhibition at 61 New Bond Street; London, W., was recently visited by Princess Henry of Batten. burg, when -her Royal Highness purchased several of Mr. Lawplough's paintings of Egypt and Nubia, visited Buckingham Palace Jast Friday by special command of King Edward, who expressed his desire to view several of Mr. Lamplough's pictures. Mr. Lamplough who will arrive in Egypt shortly for the season will exhibit his paintings in Alexandria towards the middle of December.

div.head: "OUR DIRECTOR". KAMEL'S PATRIOTISM.
div.p: There is something superb in the spectacle
of a dying soldier who, while knowing that his:
last hope is dead still faces his foe with
unmoved calm, quietly and persistently parry- |
ing such attacks as he is able, until at last the | fatal thrust reachés him, and he falls a martyr to his country, leaving a name to be honoured
'even by the opposing. forces which took his] j

life. But let us imagine that daring the mom- ents of his last stand, he had filled the with the sound of vain- -glorious. boasting, with a ceaseless song of self praise "behold me I diea martyr to the country which 'I love so well, through all the ages shall my name be] cherished as that of the noblest martyr, the most wonderful patriot 'that the world has ever known": such a man would still merit 'the praise of his country inasmuch as he: had died in her service though -it is possible that such praise would be not unmixed with contempt. Let us sup that a man whom the world had long since ceased to take seriously, whose power, iff he was really ever possessed with any, had de

ed, let us picture him as striving for the adu ation of the people.He rises upand with feve expressions | of patriotism and zeal proclai himself the chosen leader of his country, pie- tures in viyid langoagethe terrors of a vile and awful opposition (which exists only in his own imagination) exhorting the people to beware, to guard themselves from the terrible conspiracies which are encompassing them on every hand, and to tarn to himas the only being on earth which power endowed to save them. The spec- tacle ceases to be superb, even the contempt ig lacking now, and one is filled only with a sense of pity for.a mistaken brother who is making himself supremely ridiculous.
- But this is all by the way. I had intended writing of the great speech, made by our great " Director" on the twenty-second day. -of October, i in the year of our Lord one thousand
nine hundred and seven. ""Qur Director" was great, there can be no
doubt as to that, and from the tangled mass of:

controversy which fell from. his august lips I gather the knowledge that; half blinded by the spirit of true patriotism though he -may be, his vision is still sufficiently clear to enable him to see and appreciate his own greatness, equally with the lesser mortals who look up to him with veneration from the street. Some have even gone as far as to suggest that he is of more importance in his own eyes than he is in the eyes of others, but this is no isolated instance of where the ignorance of the common
herd has robbed genius of immediate re-
cognition. The details of his speech are by this time

familiar to all. Every one who could read, rich and poor, lowly and great, expended his half piastre and secured, through the medium of the press, the priceless utterances of a great man. Indeed it is safe to assert that such was thestir causedby the great event, that even Panch" in the brightest days ofits zenith, was never read with more avidity than was the great organ of 'the National movement yesterday. "Garlands of flowers" we read, were presented to the great man at the conclusion of his wonderful eff rt. Even Gladstone in all his glory never a to this, but here is an orator who has ascend with one bound to tho giddy heights of fam hitherto sacred to an Edna May or Phyllis Dar

It is a pleasant suggestion truly that halfa life mis.spent entitles aman to perfecthappiness for the remainder of his days, and this at least is the inference I draw from the remarks anent 'the centuries which "our Director" accuses the Egyptians of havingwasted. He asserts that by reason of these mis-spent centuries Egypt is now entitled to immediate and prolonged happiness. May the happiness be both im- mediate and prolonged, Director, but forgive me if I cannot quite follow your argument.
It is certainly most annoying when one has spent both time and money (no matter whose) in the making of a party which is destined' in
the minds of its promoters to become the re- |.

cognized mouth-piece of those people, who should by every tenet of right considér them- selves oppressed ; it is more than annoying, it is heart-rending, -to find the chosen legion of the oppressed refusing point, blank to act in the roll allotted to them, and' accusing the month-piece of uttering false echos ; therefore one is not surprised to find that the "Director" should wax indignant, and reiterate his appeal that there should be but one party—his own—
and but one leader —himself. And why should the fortune hunting English
leave their own country in order' to introduce
reform into the irrigation service of this, when-
they are themselves to benefit' by it? 'The re- forms are.of advantage to the Bgyptian also,
[but that is not the point. The. system was

introduced by the English, and is therefore but a part of the time-worn scheme-carefally woven wherein to ensnare the unsuspecting Egyptian, and doubtless the more dangerous by reason of the joanner, in which the venom
of pu is concealed from view. } will not deal at present with the other
numerous points which we scored at Alexandria on the 22nd., but will in conclusion re-echo from the bottom: of my heart the shouts a shook the rafters on that historio
Long live Egypt, Long live patrioti tng live Mustapha Pasha Kamel, —the most amos-
ing man in ae

div.head: MINISTRY OF EDUCATION. THE REBELLIOUS STUDENTS.
div.p: No further light has been thrown upon the reasons which prompted two of the students, who were sent to England by the Ministry of Public Instrnction, to leave their college witbout warning, and to dispatch the cable to the Ministry which has led to their immediate discharge. The first news which the Ministry received of this foolish action, came from the youtks themselves, in the form of a telegram, in which they stated that it was impossible for them to remain longer at the college and had gone to Nottingham, where they were awaiting orders to return to Egypt, or in the event of such orders not being forthcoming they would consider themselves discharged.

On receipt of this telegram the Ministry cabled to Eogland to the principal of the col. lege which the boys had left, and were informed that they had refused to give any reason for their conduct, only saying that it was iínpossible for them to remain longer in the place. The Ministry, very justly considering this action and the cable addressed to them. selves as onwarrantable impertinence, cabled after due consideration, to the effect that the boys were discharged, and they are now negotiating for the filling of their places by two fresh students who, it is to be hoped, will be imbued with a little more respect for the Ministry which has taken their welfare in its charge, than their predecessors.

Some persons.take a very long time to ar. rive at the age of discretion, and it wớold appear that these two youths are particularly backward in this respect. Had they lodged a legitimate complaint as to their treatment or whatever was troubling them, they would have been sare of a prompt and thorough enquiry, but they have acted like children, and fully deserve to receive the punishment usual in such cases.

div.head: THE LATE DR. GARNER. VALUED STATE SERVANT.
div.p: A The sudden death of Dr. Garner, which we announced on Saturday, came as a very painful shock to his many friends in Egypt, many of whom had not even known that he was unwell, his illness only dating from Tuesday evening last. Coming to Egypt in 1899, when he joined the Sanitary Department, Dr. Garner was subsequently recommended by his Department to the British Government for service with a survey party in the neighbourhood of Lake Rudolph, to which district, accompanied by Maior Bright D.S.O., of the Rifle Brigade, and Major Austin, R.E., he was eventually sent. The whole party was ultimately, attacked by a severe form of scurvey, and it was mainly due to the plack, skill, and endurance displayed by Dr. Garner that the expedition did not end
fatally. | Since his return to Egypt he has been

actively engaged in the usual work of his department in the provinces, and was for the last two years specially engaged in fighting the plague in Upper Egypt, and it was his indefatigable work in this direction that we I fear led to the undermining of his constitution in the first place.

Much of Dr. Garner's work had centred ronnd Tantab and Zagazig. He was well-known throughout Egypt, and it may be truly said that he did not possess a single enemy in the country, while his death at the early age of forty-one, will be lamented by all who came in contact with the charm of his personality.

div.head: SAFT EL MELOUK ACCIDENT. EXPLANATIONS OF DELAY.
div.p: The official report on the acoident which ocourred on the Cairo-Alexandria line on Friday last, and which occasioned such prolonged delay, are not yet to be seen, and it is therefore difficult to ascertain if the delay of four hours was justified by circumstances. It appears that there were two accidents of a different nature at or near the same spot during the one day. Our Cairo correspondent now writes that, as already reported, the first of these was occasioned by the night mail from Cairo being derailed by a bale of cotton which had fallen from an earlier train, and thereby blocked both up and down lines. A reljet train was sent for, but it was not until 7.30 a.m., wher the lines were just cleared, that this train arrived, too late to be of any assistance, and the ordinary train proceeded to Alexandria.

The accident occurred at 3.14 a.m. and at a point on the road which is almost at the maximum distance from a breakdown station. It would therefore scem that, provided that the necessary celerity was used in the despatching of telegrams etc. for the relief and taking into consideration the difficulties of time and place the delay was not inordinate.

The second accident, caused by six trucks of cotton becoming ignited on the track, occurred at 12.85 p.m. and was responsible for the second delay in the traffic, as it was not considered safe to run a train past the flaming waggons, even though the track was clear.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTÉRS.
div.p: The Ministers arrived at Alexandris from Cairo last night to attend a Council which will be held at Ras el Tin palace this afternoon under the presidence of the Khedive.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman liner "Barcelona" sailed on Saturday evening for Liverpool direot with a general cargo including 4,685 bales of cotton.
The Ellerman liner "City of Oxford" sailed from Liverpool on Saturday for Gibraltar, | Malta and Alexandria with a general cargo.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: When the Duke and Duchess of Connanght go to Malta this winter they will be accoin, panied by Mr. Myles Ponsonby and Sir John and Lady Maxwell.. IC is understood that the Duke's official daties will cause him to reside not only at Malta, but at Gibraltar, Cyprus, and Cairo, and his leave of absence will only be two months in the year. It is especially ar. ranged that his Royal Highness will take precedence over the Governors of Malta, Gibraltar, and Cypras, and the salaries of the Governors in qaestion will all be considerably reduced.
The Sultan of Tambura has abandoned his projected visit to Khartoum, having been convinced that the journey is too trying to andertake at his advanced age.
Sir Eldon Gorst is leaving Cairo in January for the Sudan and will meet Mr. Winston Churchill at Khartoum and return with him to Egypt

Lord Nunbarnholme, whose denth is announced in this morning's telegrams, was only raised to the peerage last year and is better known as Charles Wilson, of Warter Priory, and partner in the great shipping firm of Hall with his brother of Tranby Croft. He was bom in 1888 and sat in Parliament for Hull from 1874 to 1905. One of his daughters married the Earl of Chesterfield, and another Sir Charles Hartopp, and after the divorce Lord Cowley.
The P. and 0. S.S. "Caledonia," aboard of which are the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire, Lady Gorst, and Lady Mellwraith is due at Fort Said on Wednesday,
Rear-Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield has returned to Alexandria from Cairo, where he interviewed the Minister of Finance concernJing projected reforins in the Ports and Lighthouses Administration.
Major and Mrs. Comfort, father and motherJin-law of Crookshank Pasha, are staying at

the Hotel Continental, Paris, Major Comfort I was for many years manager of the Standard Oil Company, and afterwards Consul-General at Hong-Kong. They will pass a few weeks on the Riviera before coming to Egypt to join Crookshank Pasha and Mrs. Crookshank.
ToThe marriage of Captain Darell, the winner

of the Diamond Skulle who is stationed at Cairo, and Miss Jessie Bainbridge will be celebrated at the Guards' Chapel, Wellington Barracks, on Saturday next. Captain Darell is a son of Sir Lionel and Lady Darell, and the bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emerson Bainbridge.
Charlton Bey has arrived in Cairo and is staying at Shepheard's Hotel.
Mr. Charles Baehler is expected to arrive from Europe on the 7th proxo.
John Haicalis Bey, proprietor and manager of the "Phare d'Alexandrie," arrived at Alex | andria yesterday by the Florio-Rubattino mail boat,
Major Ravenscroft, Dr. and Mrs. Balfour, Mr. Bevan, Mr. and Mrs. More, Captain Ken. nedy, and Lieutenant and Mrs. Page have arrived at Khartoum from Cairo.
Mr. Frederick Manson and Mr. Howard Back arrived at Alexandria this morning by the S.S. "Osmanish," which vessel they joined at Piræus.

Mr. Hewlett has been appointed editor of the Cairo Society journal "The Sphinx." Mr. Hewlett is a younger brother of the famous novelist Mr. Madrice Hewlett, and nephew of Sir James Knowles, editor of the "Nineteenth Century."
The appointment of Sheikh Mohamed Bekheet as Cadi of Alexandria is shortly to be submitted to the Khedive's approval,

Among the passengers who arrived this morning by the 8.8. "Cleopatra," Austrian Lloyd mail boat, were Baron E. de Menasce and family, Baron H. de Menasce, Count and Countess Antoine Zogheb, Mr. Meinecke, Mr. E. Nahmann, Loutfy Bey, Mr. and Mrs. Lascaris, Mr. Paleologo, Mr. and Mrs. Elie | Piha, Mrs. Raff, Mrs. 0. Suares, Mr. Valassopoolo, Mr. R. Werner, Mr. and Mrs. Bird, Mrs. Bramley, Mr. Gripari, Mr. N. Socolis, | Mr. and Mrs. Kenneid, Mr. Moreno, Mr. Schlosser, Mrs. Wessely, and Mr. Wolf.

div.head: AN ABSCONDER ARRESTED.
div.p: The Sudan is certainly an unfavourable I place for would-be absconders. No one can escape beyond its borders without being caught up with on the way, as soon as he is "missed."

A recent incident clearly illustrates this fact. Two persons, we are told, came to Omdurman last year from Upper Egypt and started business, They were enabled to contract several debts, the settlement of which they seem to have regarded as a matter of no importance. Last week one of these "gentlemen" tried to abscond and had actually secured his ticket and boarded the northbound train. Learning of his departure
one of the leading merobante of Khartoum, n who happens to be one of the principal ore.
ditors, informed the authorities and a telegraphio warrant was despatched, by virtae of which the would be absconder was invited to return from Atbara to Khartonm by the next train,

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd hui midi).

La seance de ce matina été presque nulle. In criait beaucoup, surtout les petites valeurs 1ouvelles au rabais, mais les amateurs faisaient iéfaut. Toute attention s'est concentrée sur ia National Bank, l'Agricole, |'United et le Comptoir.

Cette dernidre a pour ainsi dire un intérét dactualité & cause de la prochaine assemblée, qui doit avoir lieu le 31 de oe mois. Pourtant, apres avoir été vigoureusement poussée nague: | re, elle perd du terrain depuis quelques jours. Aujourd'hui elle s'inscrit en nouvelle baisse de 1/16 & 2 29/32 Vancienne et 2 31/32 la not- velle.
A la faveur d'une légére demande, l'Agricole reprend de 8 1/16 4 8 3/32 et la National Bank de 21.3/8 a 21 9/16. L'action United est soutenue 4 9/32.
La Delta Land, qui avait subi la semaine derni¢re une série dedépréciations, bénéficie ce | matin d'un retour en faveur et progtesse pour ce motif de 1 1/4 & 1 9/32.
Avec une petite amelioration de la Land Bank de 7 1/8 & 7 3/16, c'est mee pr's tout ce qu'il y a d'iatéressant a° signaler.

Des offres, qui sont restées pourla plupart sans résultat, faute d'achbteurs, raménent la Ramleh de 41/2 A 4 3/8, lés Privilégiées Tram- ways d'Alexandrie de 140 & 138, la Bitre d'A- lexandrie Privilégi¢e de.1364 135, les Sucreries de 31 4 30, les Estates de 1/2 4 15/32, l'Union Fonoiére.de 4.13/16 & 4 3/4 et la Land Invest- ment and Building de 3/8 a 7 32.
L'Obligation Crédit Foncier gagne une avance de 50 centimes A 297 1/2 ,'ancienne et 254 la nouvelle.

Il a été vendo aux enchtres pabliques 100 Fanous(Land Investment and Building) au prix de 3/16-7/32. C'est ce qui a déterminé linseription du cours nouveau a 7/32, contre 3/8 hier, soit 40 % de baisse. Voila ce qui ar- rive avec bon-nombre de nos valeurs nouvelles qui ne sont guére traitées que par voie d'en- cheres.

Beaucoup attribuentla mauvaise tenue «de, notre marché & la crise.américaine. Cependant, pour étre juste, il faut ayouer qu'on ne semble pas ici fort impressionné par cet événement. dl n'ya pas de baisse proprement dite. Tout ce qn'on peat dire, c'est que les affaires sont de plus en plus rares, mais c'est 14 une situation A laquelle nous sommes depnis longtemps ha- bitues.

Vendredi passé les actions de' la Delta Land avaient fiéchi sur le bruit que le Gouvernement aurait déeidé d'établir 4 Tourah le champ d'épandage. Si cela était, la propriété que posside la Société 4 Maadi perdrait, en effet, beaucoup de sa valeur. Mais nous tenons de M. Henriques, directeur géncral de la Delta Land, de passage hier 4 Alexandrie, que la Société a été définitivement informée que les égoutsdu Caire neeseraient pas dirigés sur Tourah.

div.head:
THE AMERICAN CRISIS.
MEETING OF CABINET.
THE PUBLIC PANICSTRIOKEN.
CONTINUED SUSPENSION OF COMPANIES.

div.p: Runs continue on the Banks and Trust Companies. Six more suspensions of companies witb small capitals have taken place, but the aggregate deposits amount to 34,000,000 dollars.

The entire Cabinet, with the exception of 'Mr. Cortelyou, has met at Washington to con- sider the situation. Mr. Cortelyou to-day depo- sited 8,000 000 dollars with New York banks. Large Savings Banks are enforcing 30 to 60 days notice of withdrawalé, fearing a panic.
(Reuter)

Owing to numerous runs on the banks yes- terday and the consequent stoppages in differ, ent cities of America, the leading financiers are making impassioned appeals to the public to desist withdrawing money from the banks.
(Reuter)

div.head:
MORE EARTHQUAKE SHOCKS.
INCREASE OF FLOODS.

div.p: Another earthquake shock at noon yesterday caused a panic in Brancaleone but no further damage was done. The floods in Venetia are again growing worse. The water in Rovigo has reached to the level of the first floors.(Reuter)

div.head:
GREEKS IN MACEDONIA.
MEETING AT ATHENS.

div.p: At a great meeting held here yésterday a resolution was passed appealing fi protection to the Powers, in accordance with whose in- junctions the Greeks in Macedonia had adopt- ed apeaceful attitude, declaring that if the attacks continued the Greeks. would be com- pelled to act in self defence. ( Reuter)

div.head:
THE MOROCCAN SITUATION.
TROUBLE AT MOGADOR.

div.p: The mehallas which joined Moulay Rachid have dispersed. Moulay Hafid's position is precarious. (Havas)
Moulay Hafid has offered to the comman- dant of the Sherifian forces at Mogador 3,000 louis and the command of his army to force an entrance into the town (Havas)
By request of the French Consul 1.000 men and seven cannons have been dismissed. ( Havas)

div.head:
ELECTRIC TRAIN COLLISION.
SERIOUS DAMAGE DONE.

div.p: An electric train on the Metropolitan Rail- way crashed into a morning train standing at West Hamps station in afog. Three per- sons were killel and many injured. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE FRENCH NAVY.
"DREADNOUGHT" TO BE RIVALLED.

div.p: The supreme -council.of the navy has decided to establish a type of battleship much more powerful than the "Dreadnoughts." (Reuter)
The distress in Rumania owing to the an- eats in drought is daily deepening. (Renter)

div.head:
GERMAN JOURNALIST IN" COURT.
THE KAISER INVOLVED. AN INFLUENTIAL COTERIE.
EVIDENCE FAVOURS DEFENDANT.

div.p: The whole of Europe, and_ especially Germany, is profoundly moved by the. libel action now proceeding here against the well- known journalist, Herr Harden, who published articles in the, paper "Zukunft" alleging that the Emperor. was' surrounded and inflnenced politically by a coterie, the principal bers of which were Prince Eulen rinerly Ambassador 'at Vienna, Count Moltke, Com- mandant at Berlin, and Count de Hohenau. The articles further hinted' that this coterie was' a hotbed of detestable vices. It was elicitedat the. trial that the Crown Prince had submitted the articles to the Emperor 'and the dismissal of Prince Eulenburg and others instantly followed. Oouiidensbicerebancs bas been adduced corroborating the "Zukunft" reports. Count de Moltke, who is a plaintiff in the action, has positively denied the practices alleged, and affirmed ignorance of his intimate friends being concerned therein. Prince Eulen- burg is absent lL The procéedings reveal a deplorable state of things in a' section of the highest aristocracy of Berlin. A crowd tomul- tuously cheered Herr Harden shouting "Long Live Truth." Judgment is expected to be delivered on Monday. (Reuter)

The Harden trial has been concluded. The verdict will be given on Tuesday. Herr Harden's counsel contended that Count se compelled him to take action. Herr Ha a speech denied that the articles in the 'Zukuft", were aimed at Count Moltke, He said that Prince Enlenburg's retarn'to Germany necessitated the resumptioh of the articles. A camarilla's influence with the Emperor had led to the resignation of Bismarck and Caprivi's fall was due to Prince Eulenburg. Prince Buelow was Prince Eulenburg's creation but was now his bitterest enemy. The Morocco affair was due to Prince Eulenburg's influence. ~ Leaving the court Herr Harden was ovated : Count Moltke was protected by the police. (Reuter)

div.head:
CRICKET IN. AUSTRALIA.
GOOD BATTING BY ENGLAND,.

div.p: Marylebone First Match : England 350 runs or 7 wickets. The play was close. (Reuter)
October 26
The elvitidatvative officer of the Berthon reserve, accused of spyifig, has been arrested. Documents have been seized at his house. ( Havas)
The ensign of the ship "Ullmo," who was brought to Paris, has confessed. He will be sent to court martial. (Havas)
Farman, the aeronant, experimenting in bis aeroplane, did 77 metres in 33 seconds. (Havas)
Leopold Woellling has married civilly La Ritter, of Siberia, ~~ » °». (Havas)
President Roosevelt has authorised the
announcement. that the battleship: fleet would start for the Pacific on 26th December.
(Reuter)

div.head:
FRANCE'S DEFENSIVE FORCE.
PICQUART REFUTES ALLEGATIONS.
KING ALFONSO VISIT

div.p: The battleship "Renown" will embarl King Alfonso and Qasen Victoria at ug on Tuesday for Portamouth. Their Majesties are coming on a visit which will last a month and will be of a private nature. (Reuter)
The Chamber ot Deputies has voted unani-. mously 6,000,000 francs for relief in the flood- ed districts. (Router)
The Government has decided to constract a railway in Macao (Canton). (Reuter)
Lord Nunburnholme is dead. (Reuter)

div.head: OF INTEREST TO WOMEN.
div.p: Many so called women's complaints can be traced to disorders -ot the liver, stomach and bowels. A woman's work is more or léss sedentary ; she does not get the fresh air, the exercise, or the regular hours of rest that a man does, so that the liver becomes sluggish, the system does not get the rest it needs, and there is nota regular motion of the bowels. Constipation is one of the worst dangers a woman has to fear, and the longer it is neg- lected, the moe deeply rooted. 3 it becomes. The bowels'are swollen arid enlarged, thus displacing members of the female organism, and causing ,stomach pains, difficulty in breathing, windy: spasins, headache, vomiting, a feeling of fulness after meals, bloodlessness, etc. But men who are constipated suffer from these same symptoms, so that it cannot be female trouble. When the constipation is cured, the distressing complaints will quickly disappear. A box of Doan's Dinner Pills should always be kept in the house, and a dose taken when the bowels have been inactive, or whenever food disagrees, or when there is afeeling of heaviness'and discomfort in the region of the stomach. This medicine is purely vegetable, and perfectly harmless for menor women, young and old.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de. Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
div.p: AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de Fer de !'Etat a l'honneur de porter 41a connaissance da Public qu'elle~recevra jusqu'au Jendi six Novembre prochain & midi au plus tard, des offres pour la fournitare de 3000 (trois mille) kilos de Raton de Candié qualité extra, trés Sec. Des échantillons devront étro soumis en méme temps que les. offtes.: La livraisop sera faite franco dans les Magasins de l'Adpsinistra- tion 4 Gabbary (Alexandrie). Les Conditions Générales de.cette fourniture peuvent ¢tre consultées au Bureau Central du Service des Magasins Généraux a Boulac (Caire) et aux Magasins de Gabbary (Alexandrie) tous les jours de nenf heures du matin 4 une 'heure p.m., les Dimanches et jours fériés exceptés.

Pour &tre admis A concourir, le soumission- naire devra verser, aa préalable, 4-la Caisse de YAdministration, & titre de dépdt provisoire, une somme de L.E. 5 (Cinq Livres Egyptiennes), Le soumissionnaire déclaré adjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme jusqu'A concurrence da 10% (dix pour cent) du montant de I'offre agréée.

Les offres devront étre accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de trente milliémes ainsi que du recu constatant le yersement du cautionnement provisoire 'susvisé. Elles seront adressées par la poste sous pli recommandé s:—
Monsieur le Directeur Général des Chemins de Fer de 1'Etat,
Caire.
et sous double enveloppe, l'intérietre portant la suacription suivante:
"Offre potir foarnitare de Savon de Candie."
L'Administration ne s'en pas & adcepter Poffre la plns basse, oi A donner suite aux soumissions prégentéess Elle " réserye le: droit de diviser la cbmumgmde. . J

Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
